title: Barry Hearn slams 'deadly dull' Ronnie O'Sullivan: 'Enough of this nonsense'
text:
Barry Hearn has had enough of Ronnie O’Sullivan’s opinions (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

Barry Hearn has described Ronnie O’Sullivan as ‘deadly dull’ and has called for ‘enough of this nonsense’ after the Rocket’s latest criticisms of World Snooker.

O’Sullivan won in the first round of the English Open on Monday, edging out Jamie O’Neill 4-3, but criticised the venue of the tournament and the fact he has to play against much lower-ranked opponents.

O’Neill is number 105 in the world and the Rocket would rather not have to play opponents that he doesn’t see as ‘top players’ as he believes it is harder to have a ‘proper’ match.

World Snooker chairman Hearn has been entirely dismissive of these opinions, suggesting O’Sullivan should be ‘left out there with the fairies at the bottom of the garden.’

‘He is becoming so dull isn’t he? I mean God almighty,’ Hearn said on talkSPORT. ‘I listened to him last night, ramble, ramble, it’s like everyone’s playing games with Ronnie because all you’ve got to say is something to him and he will automatically disagree with you.

Ronnie O’Sullivan has been critical of the English Open again (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

‘I think he’s best left out there with the fairies at the bottom of the garden.’

Hearn especially took exception to the idea that O’Sullivan is ‘forced’ to play against opponents that ‘are just happy to be there.’

‘Forced!’ Hearn exclaimed. ‘It’s like Tiger Woods saying, “I don’t want to play someone who’s not ranked in the top 10.”

‘I don’t lose my patience, I used to find him quite amusing but now I find him deadly dull. I find him so boring.

‘I think he’s the greatest player in the world, I love to watch him play snooker, he is fabulous entertainment, but once he gets into a studio and goes on a rant…

‘The game has never been in a better place , there’s never been more money, never been more opportunity.

‘When Ronnie was quiet the prize money was £3.5m for the season, but he don’t stop talking now it’s £16m.

‘Yes there are kids coming through the ranks and yes he will have to play them and yes that kid is ‘up for none’ because he’s playing Ronnie O’Sullivan!

‘He doesn’t have to play in anything, he can sit at home all day, watch the tele, listen to you on the radio.

‘Ronnie picks and chooses what he plays in, now he wants to pick and choose who he plays. Enough of all this nonsense!’

O’Sullivan returns to Crawley for the second round of the English Open on Wednesday afternoon against Chinese teenager Yuan Sijun.
